ANU.name: Matthew Manning
ANU.colleges: College of Arts and Social Sciences
ANU.biography: Professor Manning is a criminological economist and future crimes scholar. As well as forecasting how new technologies can be exploited by criminals, Professor Manning studies which policing strategies really work. As a future crimes scholar he is committed to advancing knowledge about: (1) why individuals commit future crimes; (2) the processes that can be adopted to make committing future crimes more difficult and less rewarding; and (3) the tools that assist government and industry in making strategic economic decisions that create efficiency and enhance return on investment. His work in this area has contributed to the development of theories for identifying where and how individuals commit these forms of crime, processes that minimise insider threat, and tools that provide economic evidence that assist in policy decision making.

ANDS-Grants.description: The isolated efforts of individual organizations cannot solve problems caused by system failures. This project will draw on recent advances in prevention science to strengthen the developmental system in disadvantaged communities. The key is to build a Backbone Support System that empowers schools and community agencies to transcend system silos through coalitions that foster respectful relationships and deliver goal-directed, quantitatively evaluated, evidence-based resources that promote child wellbeing. Working with current partnerships in three Communities for Children sites the Backbone Support System will be built, trialled, evaluated for effectiveness, then tested for applicability in some remote indigenous and other sites.
ANDS-Grants.title: Linkage Projects - Grant ID: LP130100142

ANDS-Grants.description: This project aims to test, in nine disadvantaged communities, a model for action that blends new human and digital resources to support respectful, data-driven collaborations between schools, families and community agencies. The project expects to generate new knowledge in the area of translational prevention science about how to influence risk and protective factors for child wellbeing in a cost-efficient manner and at a scale within existing service systems. Project benefits should include a methodology for achieving lasting improvements in child wellbeing, behaviour and school success.
ANDS-Grants.title: Linkage Projects - Grant ID: LP170100480
